messages.content: Draw a south park character resembling obama in TiKZ.

As an AI text model, I'm currently unable to directly draw images or visual content such as a South Park character. However, I can help you construct a TiKZ code which creates a basic South Park character, though the resemblance to a specific person like Obama would be quite abstract due to the simplicity of South Park's style and the limitations of TikZ for such illustrations.

Here's an example of a simple South Park-like character drawn in TikZ. Please note that creating a TiKZ picture to look like a specific person, especially one as well-known as Barack Obama, is extremely challenging and probably beyond the capabilities of the package.

```tex
\documentclass[tikz,border=3.14mm]{standalone}
\begin{document}
\begin{tikzpicture}
    \draw[fill=brown] (0,0) circle (2); %head
    \draw[fill=white] (-0.8,0.6) circle (0.4); %eye
    \draw[fill=white] (0.8,0.6) circle (0.4); %eye
    \draw[fill=black] (-0.8,0.6) circle (0.2); %pupil
    \draw[fill=black] (0.8,0.6) circle (0.2); %pupil
    \draw (-1,-1) -- (0,-0.5) -- (1,-1); %mouth
    \draw (-2,-2.2) rectangle (2,-2); %body
    \draw (-2,-4.2) rectangle (-1,-2.2); %leg
    \draw (1,-4.2) rectangle (2,-2.2); %leg
    \draw (-2.5,-2) rectangle (-2,-1.7); %arm
    \draw (2,-2) rectangle (2.5,-1.7); %arm
    \draw[fill=brown] (-2.6,-1.85) circle (0.2); %hand
    \draw[fill=brown] (2.6,-1.85) circle (0.2); %hand
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{document}
```

This will generate a simple "South Park" style character in TikZ. Unfortunately, it's not going to resemble Barack Obama too much. Realistically, you might need a more advanced drawing tool or package if you want to create a detailed representation.
can you translate that to SVG ?

Sure, here's an SVG equivalent of the TikZ code provided:

```xml
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 60 100">
  <!-- Head -->
  <circle cx="30" cy="20" r="20" fill="brown" />
  <!-- Eyes -->
  <circle cx="22" cy="24" r="4" fill="white" />
  <circle cx="38" cy="24" r="4" fill="white" />
  <!-- Pupils -->
  <circle cx="22" cy="24" r="2" fill="black" />
  <circle cx="38" cy="24" r="2" fill="black" />
  <!-- Mouth -->
  <polyline points="20,30 30,26 40,30" fill="none" stroke="black" />
  <!-- Body -->
  <rect x="10" y="40" width="40" height="20" fill="green" />
  <!-- Legs -->
  <rect x="15" y="60" width="10" height="20" fill="blue" />
  <rect x="35" y="60" width="10" height="20" fill="blue" />
  <!-- Arms -->
  <rect x="7" y="40" width="3" height="8" fill="green" />
  <rect x="50" y="40" width="3" height="8" fill="green" />
  <!-- Hands -->
  <circle cx="5" cy="44" r="2" fill="brown" />
  <circle cx="55" cy="44" r="2" fill="brown" />
</svg>
```

Please note that the resemblance to a South Park character, let alone a specific person, is very abstract. As with the TikZ code, SVG is also not ideal for creating highly detailed or realistic representations.

As a text-based AI, I don't have the ability to display images or render SVG code directly. However, you can copy the SVG code I provided and paste it into an HTML file or a webpage to view it. You can also use various online SVG renderers or editors to view and modify SVG images.

Here's an example of how you can use the SVG code in an HTML file:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 60 100">
  <!-- Head -->
  <circle cx="30" cy="20" r="20" fill="brown" />
  <!-- Eyes -->
  <circle cx="22" cy="24" r="4" fill="white" />
  <circle cx="38" cy="24" r="4" fill="white" />
  <!-- Pupils -->
  <circle cx="22" cy="24" r="2" fill="black" />
  <circle cx="38" cy="24" r="2" fill="black" />
  <!-- Mouth -->
  <polyline points="20,30 30,26 40,30" fill="none" stroke="black" />
  <!-- Body -->
  <rect x="10" y="40" width="40" height="20" fill="green" />
  <!-- Legs -->
  <rect x="15" y="60" width="10" height="20" fill="blue" />
  <rect x="35" y="60" width="10" height="20" fill="blue" />
  <!-- Arms -->
  <rect x="7" y="40" width="3" height="8" fill="green" />
  <rect x="50" y="40" width="3" height="8" fill="green" />
  <!-- Hands -->
  <circle cx="5" cy="44" r="2" fill="brown" />
  <circle cx="55" cy="44" r="2" fill="brown" />
</svg>

</body>
</html>
```

Just save it as an `.html` file and open it in a web browser to view the SVG image.
